awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Was There a Shift Toward Small, Non-Fossilizing Plankton after the End of the Cretaceous Mass Extinction?
awd_abstract_narration:
Phytoplankton, which live in the surface ocean, produce organic matter from sunlight and carbon dioxide. This primary production forms the base of most marine food webs and is a critical part of the global carbon cycle. In the modern ocean plankton are being impacted by warming and ocean acidification. Natural changes in ocean temperature and chemistry in the geologic past can help us understand the long-term effects of stressors such as warming and acidification. The Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction event ~66 million years ago was one such time of global change. Calcareous (fossil-forming) nanoplankton were one of the dominant primary producers in the Cretaceous ocean. However, 93% of species of this group went extinct at the K-Pg boundary, and they were never again as dominant. Previous studies of the plankton response to the K-Pg event have generally been limited to studies of species which leave a physical fossil record. Thus, these studies provided only a partial view of ancient plankton ecosystems. The proposed work will overcome this limitation by using chemical fossils called biomarkers. These new data will be used together with traditional physical fossils to reconstruct changes in the marine plankton community following the K-Pg event. It has often been assumed that non-fossilizing phytoplankton filled the gap left by the decline in calcareous nannoplankton. This study will help test that hypothesis. Documenting the changes in both non-fossilizing and fossilizing plankton will improve our understanding of long-term changes in plankton ecology, and of how those changes could alter the ocean carbon cycle. This project will train early career researchers and undergraduate students, and will disseminate results to broader audiences through outreach and educational activities in partnership with organizations and programs in Austin, TX and Boulder, CO.

The project will develop datasets of lipid biomarkers, calcareous nannoplankton, and planktic foraminifera from 5 sites in Tunisia, Spain, and the US Gulf Coast. Three sites in Tunisia (El Kef, Elles, and El Melah) represent a depth transect on a continental shelf (paleodepths of 200-500 m), Caravaca represents deeper water (~600-1000 m), while Brazos represent a shallow shelf which will allow us to test regional variability between north Africa and the US Gulf Coastal Plain. These data will allow tests of the following hypotheses:
1.	A low-diversity assemblage of non-fossilizing phytoplankton bloomed in the aftermath of the K-Pg extinction, during the time of low diversity calcareous nannoplankton “disaster” assemblages.
2.	Subsequent recovery of calcareous nannoplankton diversity is associated with a decline in non-fossilizing phytoplankton.
3.	Shifts in the heterotrophic planktic foraminifera assemblages are tied to turnover in the whole autotrophic plankton assemblage.
4.	The post-extinction community of primary producers was dominated by smaller phytoplankton like algae and cyanobacteria, and would have increased carbon recycling in shallow waters and reduced carbon export to the deep sea.
The study will improve our understanding of the recovery after the end Cretaceous mass extinction and in our overall understanding of the role of plankton ecology in marine ecosystem change. Additionally, reconstructing the whole plankton ecosystem, and not just the part that fossilizes, would represent a significant improvement of our toolkit to investigate ancient oceans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

por.por_cntn:
Phytoplankton form the base of the marine food web and are an important component of the global carbon cycle. Modern plankton populations are already shifting their ranges due to warming waters and ocean acidification; to fully understand the implications of these ongoing shifts it is necessary to look to the geologic past and the complete plankton response to similar shifts in temperature and pH. In this case, however, using the past as the key to the future is complicated by the fact that the majority of the modern plankton biomass is composed of organisms which do not have hard parts and thus do not enter the fossil record. The non-fossilizing plankton are typically ignored in paleoecological studies of plankton, which tend to focus on fossilizing groups like planktic foraminifera and calcareous nannoplankton. In this project we overcame this problem by integrating fossil records of plankton with hard parts with biomarker records of plankton without hard parts, like cyanobacteria, various groups of algae, etc. across the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction from two sites: El Kef, in Tunisia, and the Brazos River in Falls County, TX. The K-Pg mass extinction is associated with a major decline in populations of fossilizing plankton like calcareous nannoplankton and foraminifera, and there is evidence that non-fossilzing plankton played a key role in the subsequent recovery, but this is still unsure. We aimed to test the hypothesis that there was a shift toward small, non-fossilizing plankton in the immediate aftermath of the K-Pg mass extinction, and explore what this means for the recovery of the plankton ecosystem. We found:

  1. Specific groups of non-fossilizing phytoplankton bloomed in the aftermath of the K-Pg extinction, during the time when fossilizing plankton populations were dominated by calcareous nannoplankton “disaster” assemblages and more generalist planktic foraminifera
  2. Subsequent recovery of calcareous nannoplankton diversity is associated and a shift toward more specialized planktic foraminifera is associated with a turnover in non-fossilizing phytoplankton.
  3. These ecosystems and the timing of their recovery were fundamentally different at the shallow water shelf assemblage at Brazos and the deeper water open ocean assemblage at Kef.

Overall, our work shows that the interactions of different organisms within ecosystems plays at least as much of a role in the recovery of those ecosystems as external factors like environmental conditions. This is an important for our understanding of the recovery after the End Cretaceous mass extinction and also highlights a path to better understand other critical transitions in the history of life in the oceans, as this is the first study, that we are aware of, that integrates population analysis of fossilizing plankton with biomarker analysis of the relative abundance of groups of non-fossilizing plankton. This whole-ecosystem approach should be applied to other time intervals to better understand the different ways that global environmental change can impact the plankton, and how those changes in the plankton can impact ocean food webs and biogeochemical cycling.

Additionally, our work to improve our understanding of the timing of these events by recalibrating the first biozone of the Paleocene revealed that this zone was much shorter (7,000 years) than previously thought (30,000 years), and the first new species appeared within just 3,500 years.

This project supported the training of a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Texas, a training opportunity for an undergraduate summer intern at the University of Texas, and the key results are being prepared for a nationally syndicated earth science radio show and were discussed by the PI on an earth science podcast currently in production.


Last Modified: 01/03/2025
Modified by: Christopher M Lowery

Image
  • Scanning electron micrograph of the marker planktic foraminifer species Parvularugoglobigerina eugubina from, the River Bank South outcrop on the Brazos River, Falls County, TX. This specimen is from the lowest sample in which they occur, 60 cm above the Cretaceous/Paleogene boundary.
    Chris Lowery
    Creative Commons
    Christopher M Lowery

Subsequent recovery of calcareous nannoplankton diversity is associated and a shift toward more specialized planktic foraminifera is associated with a turnover in non-fossilizing phytoplankton.
